reviewText: The ability to scale in and out to play with everything in a macro and micro level is awesome! Just like the videos show, you can create rooms, trees, mountains, and everything your mind can conceptualize and then zoom in and out to add unreal levels of detail. The demo videos showing a tree-within-a-tree-within-a-tree isn't exaggerating slightly: it really has about 6-7 levels of trees" in their demo scene.\n\nThe most fun I had with this was sampling the multiplayer (still in beta
date: but coming soon). Fire up a team Skype call
hoursPlayed: and we collaborated on a work project
voteText: where everyone was "drawing" all over every surface like they were 3D whiteboards. You could watch your teammates as they drew Godzilla-sized in the air over your heads
helpfulPercent: while you marched around the front of your sculpture like an ant. We could see
votesTotal: every stroke of everyone around us
votesFunny: and designing levels where you actually DRAW the levels together was a blast. (Don't forget to save often so you can pull up the work later on your own single-player world and review all of your collaboration from the comfort of your own room.)\n\nWhere a picture paints a thousand words
commentsCount: this tool explodes that by an order of several magnitudes. The concept was simple

reviewText:
SculptrVR is uniquely great. It is a much more powerful experience than Tilt Brush which seems comparable at first glance.

In SculptrVR you get a sense of volume in the space right away with even the default ball of voxels. The ability to scale and teleport gives you the ability to change your perspective in a big way.

The most telling thing is that my daughter made an entire island in SculptrVR as the first thing she ever did in the Vive. She made a hut with a bed, a pool, a boat and waves. Then she'd walk around in them and acted as if they were completely real.

In Tilt Brush she made flat drawings vertically in space and labeled them with names. That was despite having seen people use Tilt Brush on youtube and being very excited about building a house.

Tilt Brush just isn't quite set up for her to be immersed in the environment like she wants (and SculptrVR is). I had to lift her up to let her finish the head and hair on one person. She did draw herself a portal and stepped through it when it was time to quit though, so that was cool.
voteText: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
As far as I can tell, SculptrVR is the first of its kind in that people can use it to build at vastly differing scales. I've dreamed of an app like this for a while now, so it's not surprising that it kept me busy for several hours. However, in case the developer is open for suggestions, there are a couple of things that can be addressed:

There aren't very many options for tools; just sphere, cube, rocket, spraycan, and this one projectile-orb thing that I can't get to work (plus their eraser equivalents). I could think of a few tool ideas right off the bat that would certainly make building things faster (straight-line box fill, rectangular-prismic box fill, resolution of boxes in drawing spheres, cut/copy/paste, recolor, sunlight direction, bezier curve box fill, etc).

Also, there are only 16 possible colors for boxes, all of which appear to have the same color scheme as wool blocks in Minecraft. This is really one of my lesser complaints; I can understand if 16 colors is for memory-saving purposes, because I can tell the program was made with space-saving in mind. (I'm going to take a wild guess and say that every heterogeneous block is defined by eight smaller blocks, some of which might recursively consist of eight even-smaller blocks and so on.) Despite this, a color palette that allows users to decide which 16 colors are used would be nice.

Because this program is so new, I'll excuse these minor issues and say that I recommend this game, because let's be honest: creating worlds of vastly differing scales is an awesome and undervisited idea. I see so much potential as to what SculptrVR could become; in particular, I'm excited to see what you mean when you say Game inside the scupted worlds" on the list of things that are coming soon.

Edit: I'm not very good at actually writing reviews
date: so my bad if this was a little unfair-sounding."

reviewText:
You love pixel art ? I'm sure you do. You love 3D ? VR ? Minecraft ? Build giant and small scale stuff, full of details ?

It's all that and more. You can scale yourself as a giant to build mountains within minutes. Then scale down to carve tunnels and mines in it with missiles. And finally scale down some more to decorate your own personnal Moria with fine sculptures, so small that only you know they're there.

Also, multiplayer is coming. it's a no-brainer.

reviewText: One of the must have for HTC Vive!\nThis is one of the coolest apps/games I have played in VR. You can build worlds, you can walk on it, build in multiplayer, and destroy everything with rockets! GO GET IT NOW!

reviewText: Very cool sandbox voxel painting app. You can kind of build you own minecraft style voxel worlds and then the coolest part is to scale yourself down and teleport around the world you build. It would be great to be able to then use these worlds in a game of some sort, so I can definitely see that coming one day either to ScultVR or another game like this. I would say that the price is way too high for the current state of the app, so maybe wait until a bigger sale to pick this up one unless you really love creating voxel art or environments.

reviewText:
I like the game so far. Being able to build at multiple sizes and scale yourself is amazing.

A few suggestions to improve it:
- Expanded color palette
- Undo / redo shortcuts (tiltbrush does this with a left click on the trackpad
- Visual indicator of scale (sometimes it's hard to know what size I was at when making something)
- Block snap, at certain block size / scale combos the snapping is more of a hinderance than a help when it doesn't line up.

Looking forward to seeing future improvements

reviewText:
SculptrVR is amazing.  It really let's you just spit out whatever you can think of.  I've been using it for fun and also to brainstorm new ideas for VR with 3d sketches of ideas.

I recommend this program to anyone with a Vive and any artistic inclination at all

The one thing I'd like to see in the future is the ability to change your color palette.  Sometimes I need a bunch of autumn colors or greens or skin tones and the existing colors don't have everything I want

Great experience, great developer. You'll love it and it'll wow your friends

reviewText:
Incredible Experience!

Comparing this to Tilt Brush is apples to oranges. It has a completely different feel.

As others have already pointed out, there are a number of things that could be improved.

-more variation in color palette
-undo/redo
-ability to clone a segment and replicate it anywhere
-ability to position avatar anywhere in space ( a temporary ramp could be created underneath to make it feel less strange)
-a way to smooth an edge
-additional brushes (or create custom brushes)
-I could go on (this only speaks to the fact that this is so good)

Honestly though, this is already amazing as it is. It is amongst the top VR experiences at the moment.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a lot of fun to play around with. It's really easy to build things, and it's a lot of fun to see your drawings at different scales. Like, for example, you can sit on the ground and draw the frame of a cube at a tiny scale, then change the scale so it looks bigger than a house, and you're sitting on top of it. With this, you can create an environment very quickly by doing it on a small scale, and then see it around you at full size.\n\nDefinitely worth giving a try!

I really enjoy building in this fun art creator. Being able to export to an OBJ file is pretty slick, too.
Make sure you turn the brush to High quality mode so you can sculpt with tiny blocks to get in there for detail work.

It's well worth the money and they're adding features and enhancements quite often, which makes for an even better experience.
